summary.long: 1 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: There was a certain man from Ramathaim, a Zuphite from the hill country of Ephraim, whose name was Elkanah son of Jeroham, the son of Elihu, the son of Tohu, the son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had two wives; one was called Hannah and the other Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah had none.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Year after year this man went up from his town to worship and sacrifice to the Lord Almighty at Shiloh, where Hophni and Phinehas, the two sons of Eli, were priests of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the day came for Elkanah to sacrifice, he would give portions of the meat to his wife Peninnah and to all her sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But to Hannah he gave a double portion because he loved her, and the Lord had closed her womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the Lord had closed Hannah’s womb, her rival kept provoking her in order to irritate her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This went on year after year. Whenever Hannah went up to the house of the Lord, her rival provoked her till she wept and would not eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her husband Elkanah would say to her, “Hannah, why are you weeping? Why don’t you eat? Why are you downhearted? Don’t I mean more to you than ten sons?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once when they had finished eating and drinking in Shiloh, Hannah stood up. Now Eli the priest was sitting on his chair by the doorpost of the Lord’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In her deep anguish Hannah prayed to the Lord, weeping bitterly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And she made a vow, saying, “Lord Almighty, if you will only look on your servant’s misery and remember me, and not forget your servant but give her a son, then I will give him to the Lord for all the days of his life, and no razor will ever be used on his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she kept on praying to the Lord, Eli observed her mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hannah was praying in her heart, and her lips were moving but her voice was not heard. Eli thought she was drunk
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to her, “How long are you going to stay drunk? Put away your wine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Not so, my lord,” Hannah replied, “I am a woman who is deeply troubled. I have not been drinking wine or beer; I was pouring out my soul to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not take your servant for a wicked woman; I have been praying here out of my great anguish and grief.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli answered, “Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant you what you have asked of him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “May your servant find favor in your eyes.” Then she went her way and ate something, and her face was no longer downcast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early the next morning they arose and worshiped before the Lord and then went back to their home at Ramah. Elkanah made love to his wife Hannah, and the Lord remembered her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So in the course of time Hannah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Samuel, saying, “Because I asked the Lord for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her husband Elkanah went up with all his family to offer the annual sacrifice to the Lord and to fulfill his vow,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hannah did not go. She said to her husband, “After the boy is weaned, I will take him and present him before the Lord, and he will live there always.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do what seems best to you,” her husband Elkanah told her. “Stay here until you have weaned him; only may the Lord make good his word.” So the woman stayed at home and nursed her son until she had weaned him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he was weaned, she took the boy with her, young as he was, along with a three-year-old bull, an ephah of flour and a skin of wine, and brought him to the house of the Lord at Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the bull had been sacrificed, they brought the boy to Eli,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and she said to him, “Pardon me, my lord. As surely as you live, I am the woman who stood here beside you praying to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I prayed for this child, and the Lord has granted me what I asked of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now I give him to the Lord. For his whole life he will be given over to the Lord.” And he worshiped the Lord there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Hannah prayed and said:
“My heart rejoices in the Lord;
    in the Lord my horn is lifted high.
My mouth boasts over my enemies,
    for I delight in your deliverance.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
“Do not keep talking so proudly
    or let your mouth speak such arrogance,
for the Lord is a God who knows,
    and by him deeds are weighed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The bows of the warriors are broken,
    but those who stumbled are armed with strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who were full hire themselves out for food,
    but those who were hungry are hungry no more.
She who was barren has borne seven children,
    but she who has had many sons pines away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Lord brings death and makes alive;
    he brings down to the grave and raises up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord sends poverty and wealth;
    he humbles and he exalts.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
those who oppose the Lord will be broken.
The Most High will thunder from heaven;
    the Lord will judge the ends of the earth.
“He will give strength to his king
    and exalt the horn of his anointed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elkanah went home to Ramah, but the boy ministered before the Lord under Eli the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli’s sons were scoundrels; they had no regard for the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now it was the practice of the priests that, whenever any of the people offered a sacrifice, the priest’s servant would come with a three-pronged fork in his hand while the meat was being boiled
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and would plunge the fork into the pan or kettle or caldron or pot. Whatever the fork brought up the priest would take for himself. This is how they treated all the Israelites who came to Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But even before the fat was burned, the priest’s servant would come and say to the person who was sacrificing, “Give the priest some meat to roast; he won’t accept boiled meat from you, but only raw.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the person said to him, “Let the fat be burned first, and then take whatever you want,” the servant would answer, “No, hand it over now; if you don’t, I’ll take it by force.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This sin of the young men was very great in the Lord’s sight, for they were treating the Lord’s offering with contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel was ministering before the Lord—a boy wearing a linen ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each year his mother made him a little robe and took it to him when she went up with her husband to offer the annual sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eli would bless Elkanah and his wife, saying, “May the Lord give you children by this woman to take the place of the one she prayed for and gave to the Lord.” Then they would go home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord was gracious to Hannah; she gave birth to three sons and two daughters. Meanwhile, the boy Samuel grew up in the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Eli, who was very old, heard about everything his sons were doing to all Israel and how they slept with the women who served at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said to them, “Why do you do such things? I hear from all the people about these wicked deeds of yours.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, my sons; the report I hear spreading among the Lord’s people is not good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If one person sins against another, God may mediate for the offender; but if anyone sins against the Lord, who will intercede for them?” His sons, however, did not listen to their father’s rebuke, for it was the Lord’s will to put them to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the boy Samuel continued to grow in stature and in favor with the Lord and with people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a man of God came to Eli and said to him, “This is what the Lord says: ‘Did I not clearly reveal myself to your ancestor’s family when they were in Egypt under Pharaoh?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I chose your ancestor out of all the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to go up to my altar, to burn incense, and to wear an ephod in my presence. I also gave your ancestor’s family all the food offerings presented by the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why do you scorn my sacrifice and offering that I prescribed for my dwelling? Why do you honor your sons more than me by fattening yourselves on the choice parts of every offering made by my people Israel?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore the Lord, the God of Israel, declares: ‘I promised that members of your family would minister before me forever.’ But now the Lord declares: ‘Far be it from me! Those who honor me I will honor, but those who despise me will be disdained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The time is coming when I will cut short your strength and the strength of your priestly house, so that no one in it will reach old age,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you will see distress in my dwelling. Although good will be done to Israel, no one in your family line will ever reach old age.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every one of you that I do not cut off from serving at my altar I will spare only to destroy your sight and sap your strength, and all your descendants will die in the prime of life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘And what happens to your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, will be a sign to you—they will both die on the same day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will raise up for myself a faithful priest, who will do according to what is in my heart and mind. I will firmly establish his priestly house, and they will minister before my anointed one always.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then everyone left in your family line will come and bow down before him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread and plead, “Appoint me to some priestly office so I can have food to eat.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The boy Samuel ministered before the Lord under Eli. In those days the word of the Lord was rare; there were not many visions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One night Eli, whose eyes were becoming so weak that he could barely see, was lying down in his usual place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lamp of God had not yet gone out, and Samuel was lying down in the house of the Lord, where the ark of God was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the Lord called Samuel.
Samuel answered, “Here I am.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And he ran to Eli and said, “Here I am; you called me.”
But Eli said, “I did not call; go back and lie down.” So he went and lay down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Again the Lord called, “Samuel!” And Samuel got up and went to Eli and said, “Here I am; you called me.”
“My son,” Eli said, “I did not call; go back and lie down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Samuel did not yet know the Lord: The word of the Lord had not yet been revealed to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A third time the Lord called, “Samuel!” And Samuel got up and went to Eli and said, “Here I am; you called me.”
Then Eli realized that the Lord was calling the boy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Eli told Samuel, “Go and lie down, and if he calls you, say, ‘Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.’” So Samuel went and lay down in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord came and stood there, calling as at the other times, “Samuel! Samuel!”
Then Samuel said, “Speak, for your servant is listening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Samuel: “See, I am about to do something in Israel that will make the ears of everyone who hears about it tingle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time I will carry out against Eli everything I spoke against his family—from beginning to end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I told him that I would judge his family forever because of the sin he knew about; his sons blasphemed God, and he failed to restrain them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore I swore to the house of Eli, ‘The guilt of Eli’s house will never be atoned for by sacrifice or offering.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel lay down until morning and then opened the doors of the house of the Lord. He was afraid to tell Eli the vision,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but Eli called him and said, “Samuel, my son.”
Samuel answered, “Here I am.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What was it he said to you?” Eli asked. “Do not hide it from me. May God deal with you, be it ever so severely, if you hide from me anything he told you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel told him everything, hiding nothing from him. Then Eli said, “He is the Lord; let him do what is good in his eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was with Samuel as he grew up, and he let none of Samuel’s words fall to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all Israel from Dan to Beersheba recognized that Samuel was attested as a prophet of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord continued to appear at Shiloh, and there he revealed himself to Samuel through his word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And Samuel’s word came to all Israel.
Now the Israelites went out to fight against the Philistines. The Israelites camped at Ebenezer, and the Philistines at Aphek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines deployed their forces to meet Israel, and as the battle spread, Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who killed about four thousand of them on the battlefield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the soldiers returned to camp, the elders of Israel asked, “Why did the Lord bring defeat on us today before the Philistines? Let us bring the ark of the Lord’s covenant from Shiloh, so that he may go with us and save us from the hand of our enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people sent men to Shiloh, and they brought back the ark of the covenant of the Lord Almighty, who is enthroned between the cherubim. And Eli’s two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of the covenant of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the ark of the Lord’s covenant came into the camp, all Israel raised such a great shout that the ground shook.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hearing the uproar, the Philistines asked, “What’s all this shouting in the Hebrew camp?”
When they learned that the ark of the Lord had come into the camp,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Philistines were afraid. “A god has come into the camp,” they said. “Oh no! Nothing like this has happened before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We’re doomed! Who will deliver us from the hand of these mighty gods? They are the gods who struck the Egyptians with all kinds of plagues in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be strong, Philistines! Be men, or you will be subject to the Hebrews, as they have been to you. Be men, and fight!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Philistines fought, and the Israelites were defeated and every man fled to his tent. The slaughter was very great; Israel lost thirty thousand foot soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ark of God was captured, and Eli’s two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day a Benjamite ran from the battle line and went to Shiloh with his clothes torn and dust on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he arrived, there was Eli sitting on his chair by the side of the road, watching, because his heart feared for the ark of God. When the man entered the town and told what had happened, the whole town sent up a cry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eli heard the outcry and asked, “What is the meaning of this uproar?”
The man hurried over to Eli,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who was ninety-eight years old and whose eyes had failed so that he could not see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He told Eli, “I have just come from the battle line; I fled from it this very day.”
Eli asked, “What happened, my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man who brought the news replied, “Israel fled before the Philistines, and the army has suffered heavy losses. Also your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead, and the ark of God has been captured.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he mentioned the ark of God, Eli fell backward off his chair by the side of the gate. His neck was broken and he died, for he was an old man, and he was heavy. He had led Israel forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His daughter-in-law, the wife of Phinehas, was pregnant and near the time of delivery. When she heard the news that the ark of God had been captured and that her father-in-law and her husband were dead, she went into labor and gave birth, but was overcome by her labor pains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she was dying, the women attending her said, “Don’t despair; you have given birth to a son.” But she did not respond or pay any attention.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She named the boy Ichabod, saying, “The Glory has departed from Israel”—because of the capture of the ark of God and the deaths of her father-in-law and her husband.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “The Glory has departed from Israel, for the ark of God has been captured.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Philistines had captured the ark of God, they took it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they carried the ark into Dagon’s temple and set it beside Dagon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Ashdod rose early the next day, there was Dagon, fallen on his face on the ground before the ark of the Lord! They took Dagon and put him back in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the following morning when they rose, there was Dagon, fallen on his face on the ground before the ark of the Lord! His head and hands had been broken off and were lying on the threshold; only his body remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why to this day neither the priests of Dagon nor any others who enter Dagon’s temple at Ashdod step on the threshold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s hand was heavy on the people of Ashdod and its vicinity; he brought devastation on them and afflicted them with tumors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Ashdod saw what was happening, they said, “The ark of the god of Israel must not stay here with us, because his hand is heavy on us and on Dagon our god.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they called together all the rulers of the Philistines and asked them, “What shall we do with the ark of the god of Israel?”
They answered, “Have the ark of the god of Israel moved to Gath.” So they moved the ark of the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after they had moved it, the Lord’s hand was against that city, throwing it into a great panic. He afflicted the people of the city, both young and old, with an outbreak of tumors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they sent the ark of God to Ekron.
As the ark of God was entering Ekron, the people of Ekron cried out, “They have brought the ark of the god of Israel around to us to kill us and our people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they called together all the rulers of the Philistines and said, “Send the ark of the god of Israel away; let it go back to its own place, or it will kill us and our people.” For death had filled the city with panic; God’s hand was very heavy on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who did not die were afflicted with tumors, and the outcry of the city went up to heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the ark of the Lord had been in Philistine territory seven months,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Philistines called for the priests and the diviners and said, “What shall we do with the ark of the Lord? Tell us how we should send it back to its place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered, “If you return the ark of the god of Israel, do not send it back to him without a gift; by all means send a guilt offering to him. Then you will be healed, and you will know why his hand has not been lifted from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Philistines asked, “What guilt offering should we send to him?”
They replied, “Five gold tumors and five gold rats, according to the number of the Philistine rulers, because the same plague has struck both you and your rulers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make models of the tumors and of the rats that are destroying the country, and give glory to Israel’s god. Perhaps he will lift his hand from you and your gods and your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why do you harden your hearts as the Egyptians and Pharaoh did? When Israel’s god dealt harshly with them, did they not send the Israelites out so they could go on their way?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now then, get a new cart ready, with two cows that have calved and have never been yoked. Hitch the cows to the cart, but take their calves away and pen them up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take the ark of the Lord and put it on the cart, and in a chest beside it put the gold objects you are sending back to him as a guilt offering. Send it on its way,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but keep watching it. If it goes up to its own territory, toward Beth Shemesh, then the Lord has brought this great disaster on us. But if it does not, then we will know that it was not his hand that struck us but that it happened to us by chance.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they did this. They took two such cows and hitched them to the cart and penned up their calves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They placed the ark of the Lord on the cart and along with it the chest containing the gold rats and the models of the tumors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the cows went straight up toward Beth Shemesh, keeping on the road and lowing all the way; they did not turn to the right or to the left. The rulers of the Philistines followed them as far as the border of Beth Shemesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the people of Beth Shemesh were harvesting their wheat in the valley, and when they looked up and saw the ark, they rejoiced at the sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cart came to the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh, and there it stopped beside a large rock. The people chopped up the wood of the cart and sacrificed the cows as a burnt offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites took down the ark of the Lord, together with the chest containing the gold objects, and placed them on the large rock. On that day the people of Beth Shemesh offered burnt offerings and made sacrifices to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The five rulers of the Philistines saw all this and then returned that same day to Ekron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the gold tumors the Philistines sent as a guilt offering to the Lord—one each for Ashdod, Gaza, Ashkelon, Gath and Ekron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the number of the gold rats was according to the number of Philistine towns belonging to the five rulers—the fortified towns with their country villages. The large rock on which the Levites set the ark of the Lord is a witness to this day in the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God struck down some of the inhabitants of Beth Shemesh, putting seventy of them to death because they looked into the ark of the Lord. The people mourned because of the heavy blow the Lord had dealt them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the people of Beth Shemesh asked, “Who can stand in the presence of the Lord, this holy God? To whom will the ark go up from here?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they sent messengers to the people of Kiriath Jearim, saying, “The Philistines have returned the ark of the Lord. Come down and take it up to your town.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men of Kiriath Jearim came and took up the ark of the Lord. They brought it to Abinadab’s house on the hill and consecrated Eleazar his son to guard the ark of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The ark remained at Kiriath Jearim a long time—twenty years in all.
Then all the people of Israel turned back to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel said to all the Israelites, “If you are returning to the Lord with all your hearts, then rid yourselves of the foreign gods and the Ashtoreths and commit yourselves to the Lord and serve him only, and he will deliver you out of the hand of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelites put away their Baals and Ashtoreths, and served the Lord only.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel said, “Assemble all Israel at Mizpah, and I will intercede with the Lord for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had assembled at Mizpah, they drew water and poured it out before the Lord. On that day they fasted and there they confessed, “We have sinned against the Lord.” Now Samuel was serving as leader of Israel at Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that Israel had assembled at Mizpah, the rulers of the Philistines came up to attack them. When the Israelites heard of it, they were afraid because of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Samuel, “Do not stop crying out to the Lord our God for us, that he may rescue us from the hand of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel took a suckling lamb and sacrificed it as a whole burnt offering to the Lord. He cried out to the Lord on Israel’s behalf, and the Lord answered him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Samuel was sacrificing the burnt offering, the Philistines drew near to engage Israel in battle. But that day the Lord thundered with loud thunder against the Philistines and threw them into such a panic that they were routed before the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel rushed out of Mizpah and pursued the Philistines, slaughtering them along the way to a point below Beth Kar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel took a stone and set it up between Mizpah and Shen. He named it Ebenezer, saying, “Thus far the Lord has helped us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Philistines were subdued and they stopped invading Israel’s territory. Throughout Samuel’s lifetime, the hand of the Lord was against the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The towns from Ekron to Gath that the Philistines had captured from Israel were restored to Israel, and Israel delivered the neighboring territory from the hands of the Philistines. And there was peace between Israel and the Amorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel continued as Israel’s leader all the days of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From year to year he went on a circuit from Bethel to Gilgal to Mizpah, judging Israel in all those places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he always went back to Ramah, where his home was, and there he also held court for Israel. And he built an altar there to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel grew old, he appointed his sons as Israel’s leaders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of his firstborn was Joel and the name of his second was Abijah, and they served at Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But his sons did not follow his ways. They turned aside after dishonest gain and accepted bribes and perverted justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the elders of Israel gathered together and came to Samuel at Ramah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “You are old, and your sons do not follow your ways; now appoint a king to lead us, such as all the other nations have.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they said, “Give us a king to lead us,” this displeased Samuel; so he prayed to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord told him: “Listen to all that the people are saying to you; it is not you they have rejected, but they have rejected me as their king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they have done from the day I brought them up out of Egypt until this day, forsaking me and serving other gods, so they are doing to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now listen to them; but warn them solemnly and let them know what the king who will reign over them will claim as his rights.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel told all the words of the Lord to the people who were asking him for a king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “This is what the king who will reign over you will claim as his rights: He will take your sons and make them serve with his chariots and horses, and they will run in front of his chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some he will assign to be commanders of thousands and commanders of fifties, and others to plow his ground and reap his harvest, and still others to make weapons of war and equipment for his chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take your daughters to be perfumers and cooks and bakers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take the best of your fields and vineyards and olive groves and give them to his attendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take a tenth of your grain and of your vintage and give it to his officials and attendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your male and female servants and the best of your cattle and donkeys he will take for his own use.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will take a tenth of your flocks, and you yourselves will become his slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that day comes, you will cry out for relief from the king you have chosen, but the Lord will not answer you in that day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people refused to listen to Samuel. “No!” they said. “We want a king over us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we will be like all the other nations, with a king to lead us and to go out before us and fight our battles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel heard all that the people said, he repeated it before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord answered, “Listen to them and give them a king.”
Then Samuel said to the Israelites, “Everyone go back to your own town.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a Benjamite, a man of standing, whose name was Kish son of Abiel, the son of Zeror, the son of Bekorath, the son of Aphiah of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kish had a son named Saul, as handsome a young man as could be found anywhere in Israel, and he was a head taller than anyone else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the donkeys belonging to Saul’s father Kish were lost, and Kish said to his son Saul, “Take one of the servants with you and go and look for the donkeys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he passed through the hill country of Ephraim and through the area around Shalisha, but they did not find them. They went on into the district of Shaalim, but the donkeys were not there. Then he passed through the territory of Benjamin, but they did not find them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they reached the district of Zuph, Saul said to the servant who was with him, “Come, let’s go back, or my father will stop thinking about the donkeys and start worrying about us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the servant replied, “Look, in this town there is a man of God; he is highly respected, and everything he says comes true. Let’s go there now. Perhaps he will tell us what way to take.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said to his servant, “If we go, what can we give the man? The food in our sacks is gone. We have no gift to take to the man of God. What do we have?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant answered him again. “Look,” he said, “I have a quarter of a shekel of silver. I will give it to the man of God so that he will tell us what way to take.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Formerly in Israel, if someone went to inquire of God, they would say, “Come, let us go to the seer,” because the prophet of today used to be called a seer.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Good,” Saul said to his servant. “Come, let’s go.” So they set out for the town where the man of God was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were going up the hill to the town, they met some young women coming out to draw water, and they asked them, “Is the seer here?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “He is,” they answered. “He’s ahead of you. Hurry now; he has just come to our town today, for the people have a sacrifice at the high place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as you enter the town, you will find him before he goes up to the high place to eat. The people will not begin eating until he comes, because he must bless the sacrifice; afterward, those who are invited will eat. Go up now; you should find him about this time.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went up to the town, and as they were entering it, there was Samuel, coming toward them on his way up to the high place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the day before Saul came, the Lord had revealed this to Samuel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “About this time tomorrow I will send you a man from the land of Benjamin. Anoint him ruler over my people Israel; he will deliver them from the hand of the Philistines. I have looked on my people, for their cry has reached me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel caught sight of Saul, the Lord said to him, “This is the man I spoke to you about; he will govern my people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul approached Samuel in the gateway and asked, “Would you please tell me where the seer’s house is?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am the seer,” Samuel replied. “Go up ahead of me to the high place, for today you are to eat with me, and in the morning I will send you on your way and will tell you all that is in your heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the donkeys you lost three days ago, do not worry about them; they have been found. And to whom is all the desire of Israel turned, if not to you and your whole family line?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul answered, “But am I not a Benjamite, from the smallest tribe of Israel, and is not my clan the least of all the clans of the tribe of Benjamin? Why do you say such a thing to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel brought Saul and his servant into the hall and seated them at the head of those who were invited—about thirty in number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said to the cook, “Bring the piece of meat I gave you, the one I told you to lay aside.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the cook took up the thigh with what was on it and set it in front of Saul. Samuel said, “Here is what has been kept for you. Eat, because it was set aside for you for this occasion from the time I said, ‘I have invited guests.’” And Saul dined with Samuel that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they came down from the high place to the town, Samuel talked with Saul on the roof of his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They rose about daybreak, and Samuel called to Saul on the roof, “Get ready, and I will send you on your way.” When Saul got ready, he and Samuel went outside together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were going down to the edge of the town, Samuel said to Saul, “Tell the servant to go on ahead of us”—and the servant did so—“but you stay here for a while, so that I may give you a message from God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel took a flask of olive oil and poured it on Saul’s head and kissed him, saying, “Has not the Lord anointed you ruler over his inheritance?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you leave me today, you will meet two men near Rachel’s tomb, at Zelzah on the border of Benjamin. They will say to you, ‘The donkeys you set out to look for have been found. And now your father has stopped thinking about them and is worried about you. He is asking, “What shall I do about my son?”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then you will go on from there until you reach the great tree of Tabor. Three men going up to worship God at Bethel will meet you there. One will be carrying three young goats, another three loaves of bread, and another a skin of wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will greet you and offer you two loaves of bread, which you will accept from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “After that you will go to Gibeah of God, where there is a Philistine outpost. As you approach the town, you will meet a procession of prophets coming down from the high place with lyres, timbrels, pipes and harps being played before them, and they will be prophesying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Spirit of the Lord will come powerfully upon you, and you will prophesy with them; and you will be changed into a different person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once these signs are fulfilled, do whatever your hand finds to do, for God is with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go down ahead of me to Gilgal. I will surely come down to you to sacrifice burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, but you must wait seven days until I come to you and tell you what you are to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Saul turned to leave Samuel, God changed Saul’s heart, and all these signs were fulfilled that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he and his servant arrived at Gibeah, a procession of prophets met him; the Spirit of God came powerfully upon him, and he joined in their prophesying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all those who had formerly known him saw him prophesying with the prophets, they asked each other, “What is this that has happened to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man who lived there answered, “And who is their father?” So it became a saying: “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Saul stopped prophesying, he went to the high place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now Saul’s uncle asked him and his servant, “Where have you been?”
“Looking for the donkeys,” he said. “But when we saw they were not to be found, we went to Samuel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s uncle said, “Tell me what Samuel said to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “He assured us that the donkeys had been found.” But he did not tell his uncle what Samuel had said about the kingship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel summoned the people of Israel to the Lord at Mizpah
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to them, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: ‘I brought Israel up out of Egypt, and I delivered you from the power of Egypt and all the kingdoms that oppressed you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you have now rejected your God, who saves you out of all your disasters and calamities. And you have said, ‘No, appoint a king over us.’ So now present yourselves before the Lord by your tribes and clans.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel had all Israel come forward by tribes, the tribe of Benjamin was taken by lot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought forward the tribe of Benjamin, clan by clan, and Matri’s clan was taken. Finally Saul son of Kish was taken. But when they looked for him, he was not to be found.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they inquired further of the Lord, “Has the man come here yet?”
And the Lord said, “Yes, he has hidden himself among the supplies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They ran and brought him out, and as he stood among the people he was a head taller than any of the others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Samuel said to all the people, “Do you see the man the Lord has chosen? There is no one like him among all the people.”
Then the people shouted, “Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel explained to the people the rights and duties of kingship. He wrote them down on a scroll and deposited it before the Lord. Then Samuel dismissed the people to go to their own homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul also went to his home in Gibeah, accompanied by valiant men whose hearts God had touched.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some scoundrels said, “How can this fellow save us?” They despised him and brought him no gifts. But Saul kept silent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nahash the Ammonite went up and besieged Jabesh Gilead. And all the men of Jabesh said to him, “Make a treaty with us, and we will be subject to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nahash the Ammonite replied, “I will make a treaty with you only on the condition that I gouge out the right eye of every one of you and so bring disgrace on all Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The elders of Jabesh said to him, “Give us seven days so we can send messengers throughout Israel; if no one comes to rescue us, we will surrender to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the messengers came to Gibeah of Saul and reported these terms to the people, they all wept aloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then Saul was returning from the fields, behind his oxen, and he asked, “What is wrong with everyone? Why are they weeping?” Then they repeated to him what the men of Jabesh had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul heard their words, the Spirit of God came powerfully upon him, and he burned with anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took a pair of oxen, cut them into pieces, and sent the pieces by messengers throughout Israel, proclaiming, “This is what will be done to the oxen of anyone who does not follow Saul and Samuel.” Then the terror of the Lord fell on the people, and they came out together as one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul mustered them at Bezek, the men of Israel numbered three hundred thousand and those of Judah thirty thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told the messengers who had come, “Say to the men of Jabesh Gilead, ‘By the time the sun is hot tomorrow, you will be rescued.’” When the messengers went and reported this to the men of Jabesh, they were elated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to the Ammonites, “Tomorrow we will surrender to you, and you can do to us whatever you like.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Saul separated his men into three divisions; during the last watch of the night they broke into the camp of the Ammonites and slaughtered them until the heat of the day. Those who survived were scattered, so that no two of them were left together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people then said to Samuel, “Who was it that asked, ‘Shall Saul reign over us?’ Turn these men over to us so that we may put them to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul said, “No one will be put to death today, for this day the Lord has rescued Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel said to the people, “Come, let us go to Gilgal and there renew the kingship.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people went to Gilgal and made Saul king in the presence of the Lord. There they sacrificed fellowship offerings before the Lord, and Saul and all the Israelites held a great celebration.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said to all Israel, “I have listened to everything you said to me and have set a king over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you have a king as your leader. As for me, I am old and gray, and my sons are here with you. I have been your leader from my youth until this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here I stand. Testify against me in the presence of the Lord and his anointed. Whose ox have I taken? Whose donkey have I taken? Whom have I cheated? Whom have I oppressed? From whose hand have I accepted a bribe to make me shut my eyes? If I have done any of these things, I will make it right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have not cheated or oppressed us,” they replied. “You have not taken anything from anyone’s hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Samuel said to them, “The Lord is witness against you, and also his anointed is witness this day, that you have not found anything in my hand.”
“He is witness,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel said to the people, “It is the Lord who appointed Moses and Aaron and brought your ancestors up out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, stand here, because I am going to confront you with evidence before the Lord as to all the righteous acts performed by the Lord for you and your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “After Jacob entered Egypt, they cried to the Lord for help, and the Lord sent Moses and Aaron, who brought your ancestors out of Egypt and settled them in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But they forgot the Lord their God; so he sold them into the hand of Sisera, the commander of the army of Hazor, and into the hands of the Philistines and the king of Moab, who fought against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They cried out to the Lord and said, ‘We have sinned; we have forsaken the Lord and served the Baals and the Ashtoreths. But now deliver us from the hands of our enemies, and we will serve you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord sent Jerub-Baal, Barak, Jephthah and Samuel, and he delivered you from the hands of your enemies all around you, so that you lived in safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But when you saw that Nahash king of the Ammonites was moving against you, you said to me, ‘No, we want a king to rule over us’—even though the Lord your God was your king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now here is the king you have chosen, the one you asked for; see, the Lord has set a king over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you fear the Lord and serve and obey him and do not rebel against his commands, and if both you and the king who reigns over you follow the Lord your God—good!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you do not obey the Lord, and if you rebel against his commands, his hand will be against you, as it was against your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now then, stand still and see this great thing the Lord is about to do before your eyes!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is it not wheat harvest now? I will call on the Lord to send thunder and rain. And you will realize what an evil thing you did in the eyes of the Lord when you asked for a king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel called on the Lord, and that same day the Lord sent thunder and rain. So all the people stood in awe of the Lord and of Samuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people all said to Samuel, “Pray to the Lord your God for your servants so that we will not die, for we have added to all our other sins the evil of asking for a king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not be afraid,” Samuel replied. “You have done all this evil; yet do not turn away from the Lord, but serve the Lord with all your heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not turn away after useless idols. They can do you no good, nor can they rescue you, because they are useless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the sake of his great name the Lord will not reject his people, because the Lord was pleased to make you his own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for me, far be it from me that I should sin against the Lord by failing to pray for you. And I will teach you the way that is good and right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But be sure to fear the Lord and serve him faithfully with all your heart; consider what great things he has done for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet if you persist in doing evil, both you and your king will perish.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was thirty years old when he became king, and he reigned over Israel forty- two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul chose three thousand men from Israel; two thousand were with him at Mikmash and in the hill country of Bethel, and a thousand were with Jonathan at Gibeah in Benjamin. The rest of the men he sent back to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan attacked the Philistine outpost at Geba, and the Philistines heard about it. Then Saul had the trumpet blown throughout the land and said, “Let the Hebrews hear!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all Israel heard the news: “Saul has attacked the Philistine outpost, and now Israel has become obnoxious to the Philistines.” And the people were summoned to join Saul at Gilgal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines assembled to fight Israel, with three thousand chariots, six thousand charioteers, and soldiers as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They went up and camped at Mikmash, east of Beth Aven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelites saw that their situation was critical and that their army was hard pressed, they hid in caves and thickets, among the rocks, and in pits and cisterns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some Hebrews even crossed the Jordan to the land of Gad and Gilead.
Saul remained at Gilgal, and all the troops with him were quaking with fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He waited seven days, the time set by Samuel; but Samuel did not come to Gilgal, and Saul’s men began to scatter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said, “Bring me the burnt offering and the fellowship offerings.” And Saul offered up the burnt offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as he finished making the offering, Samuel arrived, and Saul went out to greet him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What have you done?” asked Samuel.
Saul replied, “When I saw that the men were scattering, and that you did not come at the set time, and that the Philistines were assembling at Mikmash,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I thought, ‘Now the Philistines will come down against me at Gilgal, and I have not sought the Lord’s favor.’ So I felt compelled to offer the burnt offering.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have done a foolish thing,” Samuel said. “You have not kept the command the Lord your God gave you; if you had, he would have established your kingdom over Israel for all time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now your kingdom will not endure; the Lord has sought out a man after his own heart and appointed him ruler of his people, because you have not kept the Lord’s command.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel left Gilgal and went up to Gibeah in Benjamin, and Saul counted the men who were with him. They numbered about six hundred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and his son Jonathan and the men with them were staying in Gibeah in Benjamin, while the Philistines camped at Mikmash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Raiding parties went out from the Philistine camp in three detachments. One turned toward Ophrah in the vicinity of Shual,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: another toward Beth Horon, and the third toward the borderland overlooking the Valley of Zeboyim facing the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Not a blacksmith could be found in the whole land of Israel, because the Philistines had said, “Otherwise the Hebrews will make swords or spears!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all Israel went down to the Philistines to have their plow points, mattocks, axes and sickles sharpened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The price was two-thirds of a shekel for sharpening plow points and mattocks, and a third of a shekel for sharpening forks and axes and for repointing goads.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on the day of the battle not a soldier with Saul and Jonathan had a sword or spear in his hand; only Saul and his son Jonathan had them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a detachment of Philistines had gone out to the pass at Mikmash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Jonathan son of Saul said to his young armor-bearer, “Come, let’s go over to the Philistine outpost on the other side.” But he did not tell his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was staying on the outskirts of Gibeah under a pomegranate tree in Migron. With him were about six hundred men,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: among whom was Ahijah, who was wearing an ephod. He was a son of Ichabod’s brother Ahitub son of Phinehas, the son of Eli, the Lord’s priest in Shiloh. No one was aware that Jonathan had left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On each side of the pass that Jonathan intended to cross to reach the Philistine outpost was a cliff; one was called Bozez and the other Seneh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One cliff stood to the north toward Mikmash, the other to the south toward Geba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan said to his young armor-bearer, “Come, let’s go over to the outpost of those uncircumcised men. Perhaps the Lord will act in our behalf. Nothing can hinder the Lord from saving, whether by many or by few.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do all that you have in mind,” his armor-bearer said. “Go ahead; I am with you heart and soul.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan said, “Come on, then; we will cross over toward them and let them see us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they say to us, ‘Wait there until we come to you,’ we will stay where we are and not go up to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if they say, ‘Come up to us,’ we will climb up, because that will be our sign that the Lord has given them into our hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So both of them showed themselves to the Philistine outpost. “Look!” said the Philistines. “The Hebrews are crawling out of the holes they were hiding in.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men of the outpost shouted to Jonathan and his armor-bearer, “Come up to us and we’ll teach you a lesson.”
So Jonathan said to his armor-bearer, “Climb up after me; the Lord has given them into the hand of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan climbed up, using his hands and feet, with his armor-bearer right behind him. The Philistines fell before Jonathan, and his armor-bearer followed and killed behind him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In that first attack Jonathan and his armor-bearer killed some twenty men in an area of about half an acre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then panic struck the whole army—those in the camp and field, and those in the outposts and raiding parties—and the ground shook. It was a panic sent by God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s lookouts at Gibeah in Benjamin saw the army melting away in all directions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said to the men who were with him, “Muster the forces and see who has left us.” When they did, it was Jonathan and his armor-bearer who were not there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said to Ahijah, “Bring the ark of God.” (At that time it was with the Israelites.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Saul was talking to the priest, the tumult in the Philistine camp increased more and more. So Saul said to the priest, “Withdraw your hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul and all his men assembled and went to the battle. They found the Philistines in total confusion, striking each other with their swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those Hebrews who had previously been with the Philistines and had gone up with them to their camp went over to the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the Israelites who had hidden in the hill country of Ephraim heard that the Philistines were on the run, they joined the battle in hot pursuit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on that day the Lord saved Israel, and the battle moved on beyond Beth Aven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Israelites were in distress that day, because Saul had bound the people under an oath, saying, “Cursed be anyone who eats food before evening comes, before I have avenged myself on my enemies!” So none of the troops tasted food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire army entered the woods, and there was honey on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they went into the woods, they saw the honey oozing out; yet no one put his hand to his mouth, because they feared the oath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jonathan had not heard that his father had bound the people with the oath, so he reached out the end of the staff that was in his hand and dipped it into the honeycomb. He raised his hand to his mouth, and his eyes brightened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then one of the soldiers told him, “Your father bound the army under a strict oath, saying, ‘Cursed be anyone who eats food today!’ That is why the men are faint.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan said, “My father has made trouble for the country. See how my eyes brightened when I tasted a little of this honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How much better it would have been if the men had eaten today some of the plunder they took from their enemies. Would not the slaughter of the Philistines have been even greater?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day, after the Israelites had struck down the Philistines from Mikmash to Aijalon, they were exhausted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They pounced on the plunder and, taking sheep, cattle and calves, they butchered them on the ground and ate them, together with the blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then someone said to Saul, “Look, the men are sinning against the Lord by eating meat that has blood in it.”
“You have broken faith,” he said. “Roll a large stone over here at once.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he said, “Go out among the men and tell them, ‘Each of you bring me your cattle and sheep, and slaughter them here and eat them. Do not sin against the Lord by eating meat with blood still in it.’”
So everyone brought his ox that night and slaughtered it there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul built an altar to the Lord; it was the first time he had done this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul said, “Let us go down and pursue the Philistines by night and plunder them till dawn, and let us not leave one of them alive.”
“Do whatever seems best to you,” they replied.
But the priest said, “Let us inquire of God here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul asked God, “Shall I go down and pursue the Philistines? Will you give them into Israel’s hand?” But God did not answer him that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul therefore said, “Come here, all you who are leaders of the army, and let us find out what sin has been committed today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as the Lord who rescues Israel lives, even if the guilt lies with my son Jonathan, he must die.” But not one of them said a word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul then said to all the Israelites, “You stand over there; I and Jonathan my son will stand over here.”
“Do what seems best to you,” they replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul prayed to the Lord, the God of Israel, “Why have you not answered your servant today? If the fault is in me or my son Jonathan, respond with Urim, but if the men of Israel are at fault, respond with Thummim.” Jonathan and Saul were taken by lot, and the men were cleared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said, “Cast the lot between me and Jonathan my son.” And Jonathan was taken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Saul said to Jonathan, “Tell me what you have done.”
So Jonathan told him, “I tasted a little honey with the end of my staff. And now I must die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said, “May God deal with me, be it ever so severely, if you do not die, Jonathan.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the men said to Saul, “Should Jonathan die—he who has brought about this great deliverance in Israel? Never! As surely as the Lord lives, not a hair of his head will fall to the ground, for he did this today with God’s help.” So the men rescued Jonathan, and he was not put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul stopped pursuing the Philistines, and they withdrew to their own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Saul had assumed rule over Israel, he fought against their enemies on every side: Moab, the Ammonites, Edom, the kings of Zobah, and the Philistines. Wherever he turned, he inflicted punishment on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He fought valiantly and defeated the Amalekites, delivering Israel from the hands of those who had plundered them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s sons were Jonathan, Ishvi and Malki-Shua. The name of his older daughter was Merab, and that of the younger was Michal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His wife’s name was Ahinoam daughter of Ahimaaz. The name of the commander of Saul’s army was Abner son of Ner, and Ner was Saul’s uncle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s father Kish and Abner’s father Ner were sons of Abiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Saul there was bitter war with the Philistines, and whenever Saul saw a mighty or brave man, he took him into his service.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said to Saul, “I am the one the Lord sent to anoint you king over his people Israel; so listen now to the message from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord Almighty says: ‘I will punish the Amalekites for what they did to Israel when they waylaid them as they came up from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go, attack the Amalekites and totally destroy all that belongs to them. Do not spare them; put to death men and women, children and infants, cattle and sheep, camels and donkeys.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul summoned the men and mustered them at Telaim—two hundred thousand foot soldiers and ten thousand from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul went to the city of Amalek and set an ambush in the ravine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to the Kenites, “Go away, leave the Amalekites so that I do not destroy you along with them; for you showed kindness to all the Israelites when they came up out of Egypt.” So the Kenites moved away from the Amalekites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul attacked the Amalekites all the way from Havilah to Shur, near the eastern border of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took Agag king of the Amalekites alive, and all his people he totally destroyed with the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul and the army spared Agag and the best of the sheep and cattle, the fat calves and lambs—everything that was good. These they were unwilling to destroy completely, but everything that was despised and weak they totally destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to Samuel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I regret that I have made Saul king, because he has turned away from me and has not carried out my instructions.” Samuel was angry, and he cried out to the Lord all that night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning Samuel got up and went to meet Saul, but he was told, “Saul has gone to Carmel. There he has set up a monument in his own honor and has turned and gone on down to Gilgal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samuel reached him, Saul said, “The Lord bless you! I have carried out the Lord’s instructions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel said, “What then is this bleating of sheep in my ears? What is this lowing of cattle that I hear?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul answered, “The soldiers brought them from the Amalekites; they spared the best of the sheep and cattle to sacrifice to the Lord your God, but we totally destroyed the rest.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Enough!” Samuel said to Saul. “Let me tell you what the Lord said to me last night.”
“Tell me,” Saul replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said, “Although you were once small in your own eyes, did you not become the head of the tribes of Israel? The Lord anointed you king over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he sent you on a mission, saying, ‘Go and completely destroy those wicked people, the Amalekites; wage war against them until you have wiped them out.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you not obey the Lord? Why did you pounce on the plunder and do evil in the eyes of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But I did obey the Lord,” Saul said. “I went on the mission the Lord assigned me. I completely destroyed the Amalekites and brought back Agag their king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The soldiers took sheep and cattle from the plunder, the best of what was devoted to God, in order to sacrifice them to the Lord your God at Gilgal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Samuel replied:
“Does the Lord delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices
    as much as in obeying the Lord?
To obey is better than sacrifice,
    and to heed is better than the fat of rams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For rebellion is like the sin of divination,
    and arrogance like the evil of idolatry.
Because you have rejected the word of the Lord,
    he has rejected you as king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said to Samuel, “I have sinned. I violated the Lord’s command and your instructions. I was afraid of the men and so I gave in to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I beg you, forgive my sin and come back with me, so that I may worship the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Samuel said to him, “I will not go back with you. You have rejected the word of the Lord, and the Lord has rejected you as king over Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Samuel turned to leave, Saul caught hold of the hem of his robe, and it tore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said to him, “The Lord has torn the kingdom of Israel from you today and has given it to one of your neighbors—to one better than you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He who is the Glory of Israel does not lie or change his mind; for he is not a human being, that he should change his mind.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “I have sinned. But please honor me before the elders of my people and before Israel; come back with me, so that I may worship the Lord your God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel went back with Saul, and Saul worshiped the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Samuel said, “Bring me Agag king of the Amalekites.”
Agag came to him in chains. And he thought, “Surely the bitterness of death is past.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Samuel said,
“As your sword has made women childless,
    so will your mother be childless among women.”
And Samuel put Agag to death before the Lord at Gilgal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Samuel left for Ramah, but Saul went up to his home in Gibeah of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Until the day Samuel died, he did not go to see Saul again, though Samuel mourned for him. And the Lord regretted that he had made Saul king over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Samuel, “How long will you mourn for Saul, since I have rejected him as king over Israel? Fill your horn with oil and be on your way; I am sending you to Jesse of Bethlehem. I have chosen one of his sons to be king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Samuel said, “How can I go? If Saul hears about it, he will kill me.”
The Lord said, “Take a heifer with you and say, ‘I have come to sacrifice to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will show you what to do. You are to anoint for me the one I indicate.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel did what the Lord said. When he arrived at Bethlehem, the elders of the town trembled when they met him. They asked, “Do you come in peace?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel replied, “Yes, in peace; I have come to sacrifice to the Lord. Consecrate yourselves and come to the sacrifice with me.” Then he consecrated Jesse and his sons and invited them to the sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived, Samuel saw Eliab and thought, “Surely the Lord’s anointed stands here before the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said to Samuel, “Do not consider his appearance or his height, for I have rejected him. The Lord does not look at the things people look at. People look at the outward appearance, but the Lord looks at the heart.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jesse called Abinadab and had him pass in front of Samuel. But Samuel said, “The Lord has not chosen this one either.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jesse then had Shammah pass by, but Samuel said, “Nor has the Lord chosen this one.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jesse had seven of his sons pass before Samuel, but Samuel said to him, “The Lord has not chosen these.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he asked Jesse, “Are these all the sons you have?”
“There is still the youngest,” Jesse answered. “He is tending the sheep.”
Samuel said, “Send for him; we will not sit down until he arrives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he sent for him and had him brought in. He was glowing with health and had a fine appearance and handsome features.
Then the Lord said, “Rise and anoint him; this is the one.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him in the presence of his brothers, and from that day on the Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon David. Samuel then went to Ramah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Spirit of the Lord had departed from Saul, and an evil spirit from the Lord tormented him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s attendants said to him, “See, an evil spirit from God is tormenting you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let our lord command his servants here to search for someone who can play the lyre. He will play when the evil spirit from God comes on you, and you will feel better.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul said to his attendants, “Find someone who plays well and bring him to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the servants answered, “I have seen a son of Jesse of Bethlehem who knows how to play the lyre. He is a brave man and a warrior. He speaks well and is a fine-looking man. And the Lord is with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul sent messengers to Jesse and said, “Send me your son David, who is with the sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jesse took a donkey loaded with bread, a skin of wine and a young goat and sent them with his son David to Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David came to Saul and entered his service. Saul liked him very much, and David became one of his armor-bearers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul sent word to Jesse, saying, “Allow David to remain in my service, for I am pleased with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the spirit from God came on Saul, David would take up his lyre and play. Then relief would come to Saul; he would feel better, and the evil spirit would leave him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Philistines gathered their forces for war and assembled at Sokoh in Judah. They pitched camp at Ephes Dammim, between Sokoh and Azekah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and the Israelites assembled and camped in the Valley of Elah and drew up their battle line to meet the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines occupied one hill and the Israelites another, with the valley between them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A champion named Goliath, who was from Gath, came out of the Philistine camp. His height was six cubits and a span.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had a bronze helmet on his head and wore a coat of scale armor of bronze weighing five thousand shekels;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: on his legs he wore bronze greaves, and a bronze javelin was slung on his back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His spear shaft was like a weaver’s rod, and its iron point weighed six hundred shekels. His shield bearer went ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Goliath stood and shouted to the ranks of Israel, “Why do you come out and line up for battle? Am I not a Philistine, and are you not the servants of Saul? Choose a man and have him come down to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he is able to fight and kill me, we will become your subjects; but if I overcome him and kill him, you will become our subjects and serve us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Philistine said, “This day I defy the armies of Israel! Give me a man and let us fight each other.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On hearing the Philistine’s words, Saul and all the Israelites were dismayed and terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David was the son of an Ephrathite named Jesse, who was from Bethlehem in Judah. Jesse had eight sons, and in Saul’s time he was very old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jesse’s three oldest sons had followed Saul to the war: The firstborn was Eliab; the second, Abinadab; and the third, Shammah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was the youngest. The three oldest followed Saul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but David went back and forth from Saul to tend his father’s sheep at Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For forty days the Philistine came forward every morning and evening and took his stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jesse said to his son David, “Take this ephah of roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread for your brothers and hurry to their camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take along these ten cheeses to the commander of their unit. See how your brothers are and bring back some assurance from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are with Saul and all the men of Israel in the Valley of Elah, fighting against the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning David left the flock in the care of a shepherd, loaded up and set out, as Jesse had directed. He reached the camp as the army was going out to its battle positions, shouting the war cry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel and the Philistines were drawing up their lines facing each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David left his things with the keeper of supplies, ran to the battle lines and asked his brothers how they were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he was talking with them, Goliath, the Philistine champion from Gath, stepped out from his lines and shouted his usual defiance, and David heard it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the Israelites saw the man, they all fled from him in great fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Israelites had been saying, “Do you see how this man keeps coming out? He comes out to defy Israel. The king will give great wealth to the man who kills him. He will also give him his daughter in marriage and will exempt his family from taxes in Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked the men standing near him, “What will be done for the man who kills this Philistine and removes this disgrace from Israel? Who is this uncircumcised Philistine that he should defy the armies of the living God?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They repeated to him what they had been saying and told him, “This is what will be done for the man who kills him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Eliab, David’s oldest brother, heard him speaking with the men, he burned with anger at him and asked, “Why have you come down here? And with whom did you leave those few sheep in the wilderness? I know how conceited you are and how wicked your heart is; you came down only to watch the battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now what have I done?” said David. “Can’t I even speak?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then turned away to someone else and brought up the same matter, and the men answered him as before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What David said was overheard and reported to Saul, and Saul sent for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
