verses.text: David said to Saul, “Let no one lose heart on account of this Philistine; your servant will go and fight him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “You are not able to go out against this Philistine and fight him; you are only a young man, and he has been a warrior from his youth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said to Saul, “Your servant has been keeping his father’s sheep. When a lion or a bear came and carried off a sheep from the flock,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I went after it, struck it and rescued the sheep from its mouth. When it turned on me, I seized it by its hair, struck it and killed it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant has killed both the lion and the bear; this uncircumcised Philistine will be like one of them, because he has defied the armies of the living God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord who rescued me from the paw of the lion and the paw of the bear will rescue me from the hand of this Philistine.”
Saul said to David, “Go, and the Lord be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul dressed David in his own tunic. He put a coat of armor on him and a bronze helmet on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David fastened on his sword over the tunic and tried walking around, because he was not used to them.
“I cannot go in these,” he said to Saul, “because I am not used to them.” So he took them off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he took his staff in his hand, chose five smooth stones from the stream, put them in the pouch of his shepherd’s bag and, with his sling in his hand, approached the Philistine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the Philistine, with his shield bearer in front of him, kept coming closer to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He looked David over and saw that he was little more than a boy, glowing with health and handsome, and he despised him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to David, “Am I a dog, that you come at me with sticks?” And the Philistine cursed David by his gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come here,” he said, “and I’ll give your flesh to the birds and the wild animals!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the Philistine, “You come against me with sword and spear and javelin, but I come against you in the name of the Lord Almighty, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This day the Lord will deliver you into my hands, and I’ll strike you down and cut off your head. This very day I will give the carcasses of the Philistine army to the birds and the wild animals, and the whole world will know that there is a God in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All those gathered here will know that it is not by sword or spear that the Lord saves; for the battle is the Lord’s, and he will give all of you into our hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Philistine moved closer to attack him, David ran quickly toward the battle line to meet him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reaching into his bag and taking out a stone, he slung it and struck the Philistine on the forehead. The stone sank into his forehead, and he fell facedown on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David triumphed over the Philistine with a sling and a stone; without a sword in his hand he struck down the Philistine and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David ran and stood over him. He took hold of the Philistine’s sword and drew it from the sheath. After he killed him, he cut off his head with the sword.
When the Philistines saw that their hero was dead, they turned and ran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men of Israel and Judah surged forward with a shout and pursued the Philistines to the entrance of Gath and to the gates of Ekron. Their dead were strewn along the Shaaraim road to Gath and Ekron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelites returned from chasing the Philistines, they plundered their camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took the Philistine’s head and brought it to Jerusalem; he put the Philistine’s weapons in his own tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As Saul watched David going out to meet the Philistine, he said to Abner, commander of the army, “Abner, whose son is that young man?”
Abner replied, “As surely as you live, Your Majesty, I don’t know.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Find out whose son this young man is.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as David returned from killing the Philistine, Abner took him and brought him before Saul, with David still holding the Philistine’s head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Whose son are you, young man?” Saul asked him.
David said, “I am the son of your servant Jesse of Bethlehem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After David had finished talking with Saul, Jonathan became one in spirit with David, and he loved him as himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From that day Saul kept David with him and did not let him return home to his family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jonathan made a covenant with David because he loved him as himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan took off the robe he was wearing and gave it to David, along with his tunic, and even his sword, his bow and his belt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever mission Saul sent him on, David was so successful that Saul gave him a high rank in the army. This pleased all the troops, and Saul’s officers as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the men were returning home after David had killed the Philistine, the women came out from all the towns of Israel to meet King Saul with singing and dancing, with joyful songs and with timbrels and lyres.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As they danced, they sang:
“Saul has slain his thousands,
    and David his tens of thousands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was very angry; this refrain displeased him greatly. “They have credited David with tens of thousands,” he thought, “but me with only thousands. What more can he get but the kingdom?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And from that time on Saul kept a close eye on David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day an evil spirit from God came forcefully on Saul. He was prophesying in his house, while David was playing the lyre, as he usually did. Saul had a spear in his hand
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he hurled it, saying to himself, “I’ll pin David to the wall.” But David eluded him twice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was afraid of David, because the Lord was with David but had departed from Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he sent David away from him and gave him command over a thousand men, and David led the troops in their campaigns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In everything he did he had great success, because the Lord was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul saw how successful he was, he was afraid of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But all Israel and Judah loved David, because he led them in their campaigns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said to David, “Here is my older daughter Merab. I will give her to you in marriage; only serve me bravely and fight the battles of the Lord.” For Saul said to himself, “I will not raise a hand against him. Let the Philistines do that!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said to Saul, “Who am I, and what is my family or my clan in Israel, that I should become the king’s son-in-law?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the time came for Merab, Saul’s daughter, to be given to David, she was given in marriage to Adriel of Meholah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Saul’s daughter Michal was in love with David, and when they told Saul about it, he was pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I will give her to him,” he thought, “so that she may be a snare to him and so that the hand of the Philistines may be against him.” So Saul said to David, “Now you have a second opportunity to become my son-in-law.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul ordered his attendants: “Speak to David privately and say, ‘Look, the king likes you, and his attendants all love you; now become his son-in-law.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They repeated these words to David. But David said, “Do you think it is a small matter to become the king’s son-in-law? I’m only a poor man and little known.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul’s servants told him what David had said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “Say to David, ‘The king wants no other price for the bride than a hundred Philistine foreskins, to take revenge on his enemies.’” Saul’s plan was to have David fall by the hands of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the attendants told David these things, he was pleased to become the king’s son-in-law. So before the allotted time elapsed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took his men with him and went out and killed two hundred Philistines and brought back their foreskins. They counted out the full number to the king so that David might become the king’s son-in-law. Then Saul gave him his daughter Michal in marriage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul realized that the Lord was with David and that his daughter Michal loved David,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul became still more afraid of him, and he remained his enemy the rest of his days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistine commanders continued to go out to battle, and as often as they did, David met with more success than the rest of Saul’s officers, and his name became well known.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul told his son Jonathan and all the attendants to kill David. But Jonathan had taken a great liking to David
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and warned him, “My father Saul is looking for a chance to kill you. Be on your guard tomorrow morning; go into hiding and stay there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will go out and stand with my father in the field where you are. I’ll speak to him about you and will tell you what I find out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan spoke well of David to Saul his father and said to him, “Let not the king do wrong to his servant David; he has not wronged you, and what he has done has benefited you greatly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took his life in his hands when he killed the Philistine. The Lord won a great victory for all Israel, and you saw it and were glad. Why then would you do wrong to an innocent man like David by killing him for no reason?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul listened to Jonathan and took this oath: “As surely as the Lord lives, David will not be put to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jonathan called David and told him the whole conversation. He brought him to Saul, and David was with Saul as before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once more war broke out, and David went out and fought the Philistines. He struck them with such force that they fled before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But an evil spirit from the Lord came on Saul as he was sitting in his house with his spear in his hand. While David was playing the lyre,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul tried to pin him to the wall with his spear, but David eluded him as Saul drove the spear into the wall. That night David made good his escape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul sent men to David’s house to watch it and to kill him in the morning. But Michal, David’s wife, warned him, “If you don’t run for your life tonight, tomorrow you’ll be killed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Michal let David down through a window, and he fled and escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Michal took an idol and laid it on the bed, covering it with a garment and putting some goats’ hair at the head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul sent the men to capture David, Michal said, “He is ill.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul sent the men back to see David and told them, “Bring him up to me in his bed so that I may kill him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the men entered, there was the idol in the bed, and at the head was some goats’ hair.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul said to Michal, “Why did you deceive me like this and send my enemy away so that he escaped?”
Michal told him, “He said to me, ‘Let me get away. Why should I kill you?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had fled and made his escape, he went to Samuel at Ramah and told him all that Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went to Naioth and stayed there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Word came to Saul: “David is in Naioth at Ramah”;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so he sent men to capture him. But when they saw a group of prophets prophesying, with Samuel standing there as their leader, the Spirit of God came on Saul’s men, and they also prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was told about it, and he sent more men, and they prophesied too. Saul sent men a third time, and they also prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Finally, he himself left for Ramah and went to the great cistern at Seku. And he asked, “Where are Samuel and David?”
“Over in Naioth at Ramah,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul went to Naioth at Ramah. But the Spirit of God came even on him, and he walked along prophesying until he came to Naioth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stripped off his garments, and he too prophesied in Samuel’s presence. He lay naked all that day and all that night. This is why people say, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David fled from Naioth at Ramah and went to Jonathan and asked, “What have I done? What is my crime? How have I wronged your father, that he is trying to kill me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Never!” Jonathan replied. “You are not going to die! Look, my father doesn’t do anything, great or small, without letting me know. Why would he hide this from me? It isn’t so!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David took an oath and said, “Your father knows very well that I have found favor in your eyes, and he has said to himself, ‘Jonathan must not know this or he will be grieved.’ Yet as surely as the Lord lives and as you live, there is only a step between me and death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan said to David, “Whatever you want me to do, I’ll do for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David said, “Look, tomorrow is the New Moon feast, and I am supposed to dine with the king; but let me go and hide in the field until the evening of the day after tomorrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If your father misses me at all, tell him, ‘David earnestly asked my permission to hurry to Bethlehem, his hometown, because an annual sacrifice is being made there for his whole clan.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he says, ‘Very well,’ then your servant is safe. But if he loses his temper, you can be sure that he is determined to harm me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for you, show kindness to your servant, for you have brought him into a covenant with you before the Lord. If I am guilty, then kill me yourself! Why hand me over to your father?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Never!” Jonathan said. “If I had the least inkling that my father was determined to harm you, wouldn’t I tell you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked, “Who will tell me if your father answers you harshly?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come,” Jonathan said, “let’s go out into the field.” So they went there together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonathan said to David, “I swear by the Lord, the God of Israel, that I will surely sound out my father by this time the day after tomorrow! If he is favorably disposed toward you, will I not send you word and let you know?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if my father intends to harm you, may the Lord deal with Jonathan, be it ever so severely, if I do not let you know and send you away in peace. May the Lord be with you as he has been with my father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But show me unfailing kindness like the Lord’s kindness as long as I live, so that I may not be killed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and do not ever cut off your kindness from my family—not even when the Lord has cut off every one of David’s enemies from the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David, saying, “May the Lord call David’s enemies to account.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Jonathan had David reaffirm his oath out of love for him, because he loved him as he loved himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonathan said to David, “Tomorrow is the New Moon feast. You will be missed, because your seat will be empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The day after tomorrow, toward evening, go to the place where you hid when this trouble began, and wait by the stone Ezel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will shoot three arrows to the side of it, as though I were shooting at a target.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will send a boy and say, ‘Go, find the arrows.’ If I say to him, ‘Look, the arrows are on this side of you; bring them here,’ then come, because, as surely as the Lord lives, you are safe; there is no danger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if I say to the boy, ‘Look, the arrows are beyond you,’ then you must go, because the Lord has sent you away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And about the matter you and I discussed—remember, the Lord is witness between you and me forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David hid in the field, and when the New Moon feast came, the king sat down to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sat in his customary place by the wall, opposite Jonathan, and Abner sat next to Saul, but David’s place was empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said nothing that day, for he thought, “Something must have happened to David to make him ceremonially unclean—surely he is unclean.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the next day, the second day of the month, David’s place was empty again. Then Saul said to his son Jonathan, “Why hasn’t the son of Jesse come to the meal, either yesterday or today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan answered, “David earnestly asked me for permission to go to Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, ‘Let me go, because our family is observing a sacrifice in the town and my brother has ordered me to be there. If I have found favor in your eyes, let me get away to see my brothers.’ That is why he has not come to the king’s table.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s anger flared up at Jonathan and he said to him, “You son of a perverse and rebellious woman! Don’t I know that you have sided with the son of Jesse to your own shame and to the shame of the mother who bore you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As long as the son of Jesse lives on this earth, neither you nor your kingdom will be established. Now send someone to bring him to me, for he must die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why should he be put to death? What has he done?” Jonathan asked his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul hurled his spear at him to kill him. Then Jonathan knew that his father intended to kill David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan got up from the table in fierce anger; on that second day of the feast he did not eat, because he was grieved at his father’s shameful treatment of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning Jonathan went out to the field for his meeting with David. He had a small boy with him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he said to the boy, “Run and find the arrows I shoot.” As the boy ran, he shot an arrow beyond him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the boy came to the place where Jonathan’s arrow had fallen, Jonathan called out after him, “Isn’t the arrow beyond you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he shouted, “Hurry! Go quickly! Don’t stop!” The boy picked up the arrow and returned to his master.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The boy knew nothing about all this; only Jonathan and David knew.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonathan gave his weapons to the boy and said, “Go, carry them back to town.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the boy had gone, David got up from the south side of the stone and bowed down before Jonathan three times, with his face to the ground. Then they kissed each other and wept together—but David wept the most.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan said to David, “Go in peace, for we have sworn friendship with each other in the name of the Lord, saying, ‘The Lord is witness between you and me, and between your descendants and my descendants forever.’” Then David left, and Jonathan went back to the town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went to Nob, to Ahimelek the priest. Ahimelek trembled when he met him, and asked, “Why are you alone? Why is no one with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David answered Ahimelek the priest, “The king sent me on a mission and said to me, ‘No one is to know anything about the mission I am sending you on.’ As for my men, I have told them to meet me at a certain place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, what do you have on hand? Give me five loaves of bread, or whatever you can find.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the priest answered David, “I don’t have any ordinary bread on hand; however, there is some consecrated bread here—provided the men have kept themselves from women.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied, “Indeed women have been kept from us, as usual whenever I set out. The men’s bodies are holy even on missions that are not holy. How much more so today!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the priest gave him the consecrated bread, since there was no bread there except the bread of the Presence that had been removed from before the Lord and replaced by hot bread on the day it was taken away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now one of Saul’s servants was there that day, detained before the Lord; he was Doeg the Edomite, Saul’s chief shepherd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked Ahimelek, “Don’t you have a spear or a sword here? I haven’t brought my sword or any other weapon, because the king’s mission was urgent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The priest replied, “The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the Valley of Elah, is here; it is wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you want it, take it; there is no sword here but that one.”
David said, “There is none like it; give it to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day David fled from Saul and went to Achish king of Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the servants of Achish said to him, “Isn’t this David, the king of the land? Isn’t he the one they sing about in their dances:
“‘Saul has slain his thousands,
    and David his tens of thousands’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took these words to heart and was very much afraid of Achish king of Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he pretended to be insane in their presence; and while he was in their hands he acted like a madman, making marks on the doors of the gate and letting saliva run down his beard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Achish said to his servants, “Look at the man! He is insane! Why bring him to me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Am I so short of madmen that you have to bring this fellow here to carry on like this in front of me? Must this man come into my house?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David left Gath and escaped to the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and his father’s household heard about it, they went down to him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All those who were in distress or in debt or discontented gathered around him, and he became their commander. About four hundred men were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there David went to Mizpah in Moab and said to the king of Moab, “Would you let my father and mother come and stay with you until I learn what God will do for me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he left them with the king of Moab, and they stayed with him as long as David was in the stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the prophet Gad said to David, “Do not stay in the stronghold. Go into the land of Judah.” So David left and went to the forest of Hereth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Saul heard that David and his men had been discovered. And Saul was seated, spear in hand, under the tamarisk tree on the hill at Gibeah, with all his officials standing at his side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Listen, men of Benjamin! Will the son of Jesse give all of you fields and vineyards? Will he make all of you commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is that why you have all conspired against me? No one tells me when my son makes a covenant with the son of Jesse. None of you is concerned about me or tells me that my son has incited my servant to lie in wait for me, as he does today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Doeg the Edomite, who was standing with Saul’s officials, said, “I saw the son of Jesse come to Ahimelek son of Ahitub at Nob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahimelek inquired of the Lord for him; he also gave him provisions and the sword of Goliath the Philistine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king sent for the priest Ahimelek son of Ahitub and all the men of his family, who were the priests at Nob, and they all came to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul said, “Listen now, son of Ahitub.”
“Yes, my lord,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul said to him, “Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, giving him bread and a sword and inquiring of God for him, so that he has rebelled against me and lies in wait for me, as he does today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahimelek answered the king, “Who of all your servants is as loyal as David, the king’s son-in-law, captain of your bodyguard and highly respected in your household?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Was that day the first time I inquired of God for him? Of course not! Let not the king accuse your servant or any of his father’s family, for your servant knows nothing at all about this whole affair.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said, “You will surely die, Ahimelek, you and your whole family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the king ordered the guards at his side: “Turn and kill the priests of the Lord, because they too have sided with David. They knew he was fleeing, yet they did not tell me.”
But the king’s officials were unwilling to raise a hand to strike the priests of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king then ordered Doeg, “You turn and strike down the priests.” So Doeg the Edomite turned and struck them down. That day he killed eighty-five men who wore the linen ephod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also put to the sword Nob, the town of the priests, with its men and women, its children and infants, and its cattle, donkeys and sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But one son of Ahimelek son of Ahitub, named Abiathar, escaped and fled to join David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told David that Saul had killed the priests of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Abiathar, “That day, when Doeg the Edomite was there, I knew he would be sure to tell Saul. I am responsible for the death of your whole family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay with me; don’t be afraid. The man who wants to kill you is trying to kill me too. You will be safe with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David was told, “Look, the Philistines are fighting against Keilah and are looting the threshing floors,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he inquired of the Lord, saying, “Shall I go and attack these Philistines?”
The Lord answered him, “Go, attack the Philistines and save Keilah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David’s men said to him, “Here in Judah we are afraid. How much more, then, if we go to Keilah against the Philistine forces!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again David inquired of the Lord, and the Lord answered him, “Go down to Keilah, for I am going to give the Philistines into your hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men went to Keilah, fought the Philistines and carried off their livestock. He inflicted heavy losses on the Philistines and saved the people of Keilah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Abiathar son of Ahimelek had brought the ephod down with him when he fled to David at Keilah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was told that David had gone to Keilah, and he said, “God has delivered him into my hands, for David has imprisoned himself by entering a town with gates and bars.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Saul called up all his forces for battle, to go down to Keilah to besiege David and his men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David learned that Saul was plotting against him, he said to Abiathar the priest, “Bring the ephod.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “Lord, God of Israel, your servant has heard definitely that Saul plans to come to Keilah and destroy the town on account of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will the citizens of Keilah surrender me to him? Will Saul come down, as your servant has heard? Lord, God of Israel, tell your servant.”
And the Lord said, “He will.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Again David asked, “Will the citizens of Keilah surrender me and my men to Saul?”
And the Lord said, “They will.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men, about six hundred in number, left Keilah and kept moving from place to place. When Saul was told that David had escaped from Keilah, he did not go there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David stayed in the wilderness strongholds and in the hills of the Desert of Ziph. Day after day Saul searched for him, but God did not give David into his hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While David was at Horesh in the Desert of Ziph, he learned that Saul had come out to take his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Saul’s son Jonathan went to David at Horesh and helped him find strength in God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t be afraid,” he said. “My father Saul will not lay a hand on you. You will be king over Israel, and I will be second to you. Even my father Saul knows this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two of them made a covenant before the Lord. Then Jonathan went home, but David remained at Horesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ziphites went up to Saul at Gibeah and said, “Is not David hiding among us in the strongholds at Horesh, on the hill of Hakilah, south of Jeshimon?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Your Majesty, come down whenever it pleases you to do so, and we will be responsible for giving him into your hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul replied, “The Lord bless you for your concern for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go and get more information. Find out where David usually goes and who has seen him there. They tell me he is very crafty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Find out about all the hiding places he uses and come back to me with definite information. Then I will go with you; if he is in the area, I will track him down among all the clans of Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they set out and went to Ziph ahead of Saul. Now David and his men were in the Desert of Maon, in the Arabah south of Jeshimon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul and his men began the search, and when David was told about it, he went down to the rock and stayed in the Desert of Maon. When Saul heard this, he went into the Desert of Maon in pursuit of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul was going along one side of the mountain, and David and his men were on the other side, hurrying to get away from Saul. As Saul and his forces were closing in on David and his men to capture them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a messenger came to Saul, saying, “Come quickly! The Philistines are raiding the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul broke off his pursuit of David and went to meet the Philistines. That is why they call this place Sela Hammahlekoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And David went up from there and lived in the strongholds of En Gedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Saul returned from pursuing the Philistines, he was told, “David is in the Desert of En Gedi.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul took three thousand able young men from all Israel and set out to look for David and his men near the Crags of the Wild Goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He came to the sheep pens along the way; a cave was there, and Saul went in to relieve himself. David and his men were far back in the cave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men said, “This is the day the Lord spoke of when he said to you, ‘I will give your enemy into your hands for you to deal with as you wish.’” Then David crept up unnoticed and cut off a corner of Saul’s robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward, David was conscience-stricken for having cut off a corner of his robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his men, “The Lord forbid that I should do such a thing to my master, the Lord’s anointed, or lay my hand on him; for he is the anointed of the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With these words David sharply rebuked his men and did not allow them to attack Saul. And Saul left the cave and went his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David went out of the cave and called out to Saul, “My lord the king!” When Saul looked behind him, David bowed down and prostrated himself with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to Saul, “Why do you listen when men say, ‘David is bent on harming you’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This day you have seen with your own eyes how the Lord delivered you into my hands in the cave. Some urged me to kill you, but I spared you; I said, ‘I will not lay my hand on my lord, because he is the Lord’s anointed.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See, my father, look at this piece of your robe in my hand! I cut off the corner of your robe but did not kill you. See that there is nothing in my hand to indicate that I am guilty of wrongdoing or rebellion. I have not wronged you, but you are hunting me down to take my life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord judge between you and me. And may the Lord avenge the wrongs you have done to me, but my hand will not touch you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the old saying goes, ‘From evildoers come evil deeds,’ so my hand will not touch you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Against whom has the king of Israel come out? Who are you pursuing? A dead dog? A flea?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord be our judge and decide between us. May he consider my cause and uphold it; may he vindicate me by delivering me from your hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David finished saying this, Saul asked, “Is that your voice, David my son?” And he wept aloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You are more righteous than I,” he said. “You have treated me well, but I have treated you badly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have just now told me about the good you did to me; the Lord delivered me into your hands, but you did not kill me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a man finds his enemy, does he let him get away unharmed? May the Lord reward you well for the way you treated me today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that you will surely be king and that the kingdom of Israel will be established in your hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now swear to me by the Lord that you will not kill off my descendants or wipe out my name from my father’s family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David gave his oath to Saul. Then Saul returned home, but David and his men went up to the stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Samuel died, and all Israel assembled and mourned for him; and they buried him at his home in Ramah. Then David moved down into the Desert of Paran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A certain man in Maon, who had property there at Carmel, was very wealthy. He had a thousand goats and three thousand sheep, which he was shearing in Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His name was Nabal and his wife’s name was Abigail. She was an intelligent and beautiful woman, but her husband was surly and mean in his dealings—he was a Calebite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While David was in the wilderness, he heard that Nabal was shearing sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he sent ten young men and said to them, “Go up to Nabal at Carmel and greet him in my name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to him: ‘Long life to you! Good health to you and your household! And good health to all that is yours!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘Now I hear that it is sheep-shearing time. When your shepherds were with us, we did not mistreat them, and the whole time they were at Carmel nothing of theirs was missing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ask your own servants and they will tell you. Therefore be favorable toward my men, since we come at a festive time. Please give your servants and your son David whatever you can find for them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David’s men arrived, they gave Nabal this message in David’s name. Then they waited.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nabal answered David’s servants, “Who is this David? Who is this son of Jesse? Many servants are breaking away from their masters these days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should I take my bread and water, and the meat I have slaughtered for my shearers, and give it to men coming from who knows where?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s men turned around and went back. When they arrived, they reported every word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to his men, “Each of you strap on your sword!” So they did, and David strapped his on as well. About four hundred men went up with David, while two hundred stayed with the supplies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the servants told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, “David sent messengers from the wilderness to give our master his greetings, but he hurled insults at them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet these men were very good to us. They did not mistreat us, and the whole time we were out in the fields near them nothing was missing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Night and day they were a wall around us the whole time we were herding our sheep near them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now think it over and see what you can do, because disaster is hanging over our master and his whole household. He is such a wicked man that no one can talk to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abigail acted quickly. She took two hundred loaves of bread, two skins of wine, five dressed sheep, five seahs of roasted grain, a hundred cakes of raisins and two hundred cakes of pressed figs, and loaded them on donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she told her servants, “Go on ahead; I’ll follow you.” But she did not tell her husband Nabal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she came riding her donkey into a mountain ravine, there were David and his men descending toward her, and she met them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had just said, “It’s been useless—all my watching over this fellow’s property in the wilderness so that nothing of his was missing. He has paid me back evil for good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God deal with David, be it ever so severely, if by morning I leave alive one male of all who belong to him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abigail saw David, she quickly got off her donkey and bowed down before David with her face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She fell at his feet and said: “Pardon your servant, my lord, and let me speak to you; hear what your servant has to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please pay no attention, my lord, to that wicked man Nabal. He is just like his name—his name means Fool, and folly goes with him. And as for me, your servant, I did not see the men my lord sent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, my lord, as surely as the Lord your God lives and as you live, since the Lord has kept you from bloodshed and from avenging yourself with your own hands, may your enemies and all who are intent on harming my lord be like Nabal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And let this gift, which your servant has brought to my lord, be given to the men who follow you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Please forgive your servant’s presumption. The Lord your God will certainly make a lasting dynasty for my lord, because you fight the Lord’s battles, and no wrongdoing will be found in you as long as you live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even though someone is pursuing you to take your life, the life of my lord will be bound securely in the bundle of the living by the Lord your God, but the lives of your enemies he will hurl away as from the pocket of a sling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord has fulfilled for my lord every good thing he promised concerning him and has appointed him ruler over Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: my lord will not have on his conscience the staggering burden of needless bloodshed or of having avenged himself. And when the Lord your God has brought my lord success, remember your servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Abigail, “Praise be to the Lord, the God of Israel, who has sent you today to meet me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May you be blessed for your good judgment and for keeping me from bloodshed this day and from avenging myself with my own hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Otherwise, as surely as the Lord, the God of Israel, lives, who has kept me from harming you, if you had not come quickly to meet me, not one male belonging to Nabal would have been left alive by daybreak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David accepted from her hand what she had brought him and said, “Go home in peace. I have heard your words and granted your request.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abigail went to Nabal, he was in the house holding a banquet like that of a king. He was in high spirits and very drunk. So she told him nothing at all until daybreak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then in the morning, when Nabal was sober, his wife told him all these things, and his heart failed him and he became like a stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About ten days later, the Lord struck Nabal and he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, “Praise be to the Lord, who has upheld my cause against Nabal for treating me with contempt. He has kept his servant from doing wrong and has brought Nabal’s wrongdoing down on his own head.”
Then David sent word to Abigail, asking her to become his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His servants went to Carmel and said to Abigail, “David has sent us to you to take you to become his wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She bowed down with her face to the ground and said, “I am your servant and am ready to serve you and wash the feet of my lord’s servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abigail quickly got on a donkey and, attended by her five female servants, went with David’s messengers and became his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had also married Ahinoam of Jezreel, and they both were his wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Saul had given his daughter Michal, David’s wife, to Paltiel son of Laish, who was from Gallim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ziphites went to Saul at Gibeah and said, “Is not David hiding on the hill of Hakilah, which faces Jeshimon?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul went down to the Desert of Ziph, with his three thousand select Israelite troops, to search there for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul made his camp beside the road on the hill of Hakilah facing Jeshimon, but David stayed in the wilderness. When he saw that Saul had followed him there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he sent out scouts and learned that Saul had definitely arrived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David set out and went to the place where Saul had camped. He saw where Saul and Abner son of Ner, the commander of the army, had lain down. Saul was lying inside the camp, with the army encamped around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David then asked Ahimelek the Hittite and Abishai son of Zeruiah, Joab’s brother, “Who will go down into the camp with me to Saul?”
“I’ll go with you,” said Abishai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and Abishai went to the army by night, and there was Saul, lying asleep inside the camp with his spear stuck in the ground near his head. Abner and the soldiers were lying around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai said to David, “Today God has delivered your enemy into your hands. Now let me pin him to the ground with one thrust of the spear; I won’t strike him twice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said to Abishai, “Don’t destroy him! Who can lay a hand on the Lord’s anointed and be guiltless?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as the Lord lives,” he said, “the Lord himself will strike him, or his time will come and he will die, or he will go into battle and perish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord forbid that I should lay a hand on the Lord’s anointed. Now get the spear and water jug that are near his head, and let’s go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David took the spear and water jug near Saul’s head, and they left. No one saw or knew about it, nor did anyone wake up. They were all sleeping, because the Lord had put them into a deep sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David crossed over to the other side and stood on top of the hill some distance away; there was a wide space between them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He called out to the army and to Abner son of Ner, “Aren’t you going to answer me, Abner?”
Abner replied, “Who are you who calls to the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “You’re a man, aren’t you? And who is like you in Israel? Why didn’t you guard your lord the king? Someone came to destroy your lord the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What you have done is not good. As surely as the Lord lives, you and your men must die, because you did not guard your master, the Lord’s anointed. Look around you. Where are the king’s spear and water jug that were near his head?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul recognized David’s voice and said, “Is that your voice, David my son?”
David replied, “Yes it is, my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he added, “Why is my lord pursuing his servant? What have I done, and what wrong am I guilty of?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now let my lord the king listen to his servant’s words. If the Lord has incited you against me, then may he accept an offering. If, however, people have done it, may they be cursed before the Lord! They have driven me today from my share in the Lord’s inheritance and have said, ‘Go, serve other gods.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now do not let my blood fall to the ground far from the presence of the Lord. The king of Israel has come out to look for a flea—as one hunts a partridge in the mountains.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Saul said, “I have sinned. Come back, David my son. Because you considered my life precious today, I will not try to harm you again. Surely I have acted like a fool and have been terribly wrong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Here is the king’s spear,” David answered. “Let one of your young men come over and get it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord rewards everyone for their righteousness and faithfulness. The Lord delivered you into my hands today, but I would not lay a hand on the Lord’s anointed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as I valued your life today, so may the Lord value my life and deliver me from all trouble.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Saul said to David, “May you be blessed, David my son; you will do great things and surely triumph.”
So David went on his way, and Saul returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David thought to himself, “One of these days I will be destroyed by the hand of Saul. The best thing I can do is to escape to the land of the Philistines. Then Saul will give up searching for me anywhere in Israel, and I will slip out of his hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and the six hundred men with him left and went over to Achish son of Maok king of Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men settled in Gath with Achish. Each man had his family with him, and David had his two wives: Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail of Carmel, the widow of Nabal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul was told that David had fled to Gath, he no longer searched for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Achish, “If I have found favor in your eyes, let a place be assigned to me in one of the country towns, that I may live there. Why should your servant live in the royal city with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So on that day Achish gave him Ziklag, and it has belonged to the kings of Judah ever since.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David lived in Philistine territory a year and four months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now David and his men went up and raided the Geshurites, the Girzites and the Amalekites. (From ancient times these peoples had lived in the land extending to Shur and Egypt.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever David attacked an area, he did not leave a man or woman alive, but took sheep and cattle, donkeys and camels, and clothes. Then he returned to Achish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Achish asked, “Where did you go raiding today?” David would say, “Against the Negev of Judah” or “Against the Negev of Jerahmeel” or “Against the Negev of the Kenites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did not leave a man or woman alive to be brought to Gath, for he thought, “They might inform on us and say, ‘This is what David did.’” And such was his practice as long as he lived in Philistine territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Achish trusted David and said to himself, “He has become so obnoxious to his people, the Israelites, that he will be my servant for life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days the Philistines gathered their forces to fight against Israel. Achish said to David, “You must understand that you and your men will accompany me in the army.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David said, “Then you will see for yourself what your servant can do.”
Achish replied, “Very well, I will make you my bodyguard for life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Samuel was dead, and all Israel had mourned for him and buried him in his own town of Ramah. Saul had expelled the mediums and spiritists from the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines assembled and came and set up camp at Shunem, while Saul gathered all Israel and set up camp at Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul saw the Philistine army, he was afraid; terror filled his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He inquired of the Lord, but the Lord did not answer him by dreams or Urim or prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul then said to his attendants, “Find me a woman who is a medium, so I may go and inquire of her.”
“There is one in Endor,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul disguised himself, putting on other clothes, and at night he and two men went to the woman. “Consult a spirit for me,” he said, “and bring up for me the one I name.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the woman said to him, “Surely you know what Saul has done. He has cut off the mediums and spiritists from the land. Why have you set a trap for my life to bring about my death?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul swore to her by the Lord, “As surely as the Lord lives, you will not be punished for this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the woman asked, “Whom shall I bring up for you?”
“Bring up Samuel,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman saw Samuel, she cried out at the top of her voice and said to Saul, “Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said to her, “Don’t be afraid. What do you see?”
The woman said, “I see a ghostly figure coming up out of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What does he look like?” he asked.
“An old man wearing a robe is coming up,” she said.
Then Saul knew it was Samuel, and he bowed down and prostrated himself with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Samuel said to Saul, “Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?”
“I am in great distress,” Saul said. “The Philistines are fighting against me, and God has departed from me. He no longer answers me, either by prophets or by dreams. So I have called on you to tell me what to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samuel said, “Why do you consult me, now that the Lord has departed from you and become your enemy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has done what he predicted through me. The Lord has torn the kingdom out of your hands and given it to one of your neighbors—to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because you did not obey the Lord or carry out his fierce wrath against the Amalekites, the Lord has done this to you today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will deliver both Israel and you into the hands of the Philistines, and tomorrow you and your sons will be with me. The Lord will also give the army of Israel into the hands of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Immediately Saul fell full length on the ground, filled with fear because of Samuel’s words. His strength was gone, for he had eaten nothing all that day and all that night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman came to Saul and saw that he was greatly shaken, she said, “Look, your servant has obeyed you. I took my life in my hands and did what you told me to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now please listen to your servant and let me give you some food so you may eat and have the strength to go on your way.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He refused and said, “I will not eat.”
But his men joined the woman in urging him, and he listened to them. He got up from the ground and sat on the couch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman had a fattened calf at the house, which she butchered at once. She took some flour, kneaded it and baked bread without yeast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she set it before Saul and his men, and they ate. That same night they got up and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines gathered all their forces at Aphek, and Israel camped by the spring in Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Philistine rulers marched with their units of hundreds and thousands, David and his men were marching at the rear with Achish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The commanders of the Philistines asked, “What about these Hebrews?”
Achish replied, “Is this not David, who was an officer of Saul king of Israel? He has already been with me for over a year, and from the day he left Saul until now, I have found no fault in him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Philistine commanders were angry with Achish and said, “Send the man back, that he may return to the place you assigned him. He must not go with us into battle, or he will turn against us during the fighting. How better could he regain his master’s favor than by taking the heads of our own men?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isn’t this the David they sang about in their dances:
“‘Saul has slain his thousands,
    and David his tens of thousands’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Achish called David and said to him, “As surely as the Lord lives, you have been reliable, and I would be pleased to have you serve with me in the army. From the day you came to me until today, I have found no fault in you, but the rulers don’t approve of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now turn back and go in peace; do nothing to displease the Philistine rulers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But what have I done?” asked David. “What have you found against your servant from the day I came to you until now? Why can’t I go and fight against the enemies of my lord the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Achish answered, “I know that you have been as pleasing in my eyes as an angel of God; nevertheless, the Philistine commanders have said, ‘He must not go up with us into battle.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now get up early, along with your master’s servants who have come with you, and leave in the morning as soon as it is light.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men got up early in the morning to go back to the land of the Philistines, and the Philistines went up to Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men reached Ziklag on the third day. Now the Amalekites had raided the Negev and Ziklag. They had attacked Ziklag and burned it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and had taken captive the women and everyone else in it, both young and old. They killed none of them, but carried them off as they went on their way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David and his men reached Ziklag, they found it destroyed by fire and their wives and sons and daughters taken captive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men wept aloud until they had no strength left to weep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s two wives had been captured—Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal of Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was greatly distressed because the men were talking of stoning him; each one was bitter in spirit because of his sons and daughters. But David found strength in the Lord his God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Abiathar the priest, the son of Ahimelek, “Bring me the ephod.” Abiathar brought it to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and David inquired of the Lord, “Shall I pursue this raiding party? Will I overtake them?”
“Pursue them,” he answered. “You will certainly overtake them and succeed in the rescue.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and the six hundred men with him came to the Besor Valley, where some stayed behind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two hundred of them were too exhausted to cross the valley, but David and the other four hundred continued the pursuit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They found an Egyptian in a field and brought him to David. They gave him water to drink and food to eat—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: part of a cake of pressed figs and two cakes of raisins. He ate and was revived, for he had not eaten any food or drunk any water for three days and three nights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked him, “Who do you belong to? Where do you come from?”
He said, “I am an Egyptian, the slave of an Amalekite. My master abandoned me when I became ill three days ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We raided the Negev of the Kerethites, some territory belonging to Judah and the Negev of Caleb. And we burned Ziklag.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked him, “Can you lead me down to this raiding party?”
He answered, “Swear to me before God that you will not kill me or hand me over to my master, and I will take you down to them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He led David down, and there they were, scattered over the countryside, eating, drinking and reveling because of the great amount of plunder they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David fought them from dusk until the evening of the next day, and none of them got away, except four hundred young men who rode off on camels and fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David recovered everything the Amalekites had taken, including his two wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nothing was missing: young or old, boy or girl, plunder or anything else they had taken. David brought everything back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took all the flocks and herds, and his men drove them ahead of the other livestock, saying, “This is David’s plunder.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David came to the two hundred men who had been too exhausted to follow him and who were left behind at the Besor Valley. They came out to meet David and the men with him. As David and his men approached, he asked them how they were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But all the evil men and troublemakers among David’s followers said, “Because they did not go out with us, we will not share with them the plunder we recovered. However, each man may take his wife and children and go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David replied, “No, my brothers, you must not do that with what the Lord has given us. He has protected us and delivered into our hands the raiding party that came against us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who will listen to what you say? The share of the man who stayed with the supplies is to be the same as that of him who went down to the battle. All will share alike.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David made this a statute and ordinance for Israel from that day to this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David reached Ziklag, he sent some of the plunder to the elders of Judah, who were his friends, saying, “Here is a gift for you from the plunder of the Lord’s enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent it to those who were in Bethel, Ramoth Negev and Jattir;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to those in Aroer, Siphmoth, Eshtemoa
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Rakal; to those in the towns of the Jerahmeelites and the Kenites;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to those in Hormah, Bor Ashan, Athak
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Hebron; and to those in all the other places where he and his men had roamed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Philistines fought against Israel; the Israelites fled before them, and many fell dead on Mount Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines were in hot pursuit of Saul and his sons, and they killed his sons Jonathan, Abinadab and Malki-Shua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fighting grew fierce around Saul, and when the archers overtook him, they wounded him critically.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul said to his armor-bearer, “Draw your sword and run me through, or these uncircumcised fellows will come and run me through and abuse me.”
But his armor-bearer was terrified and would not do it; so Saul took his own sword and fell on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he too fell on his sword and died with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul and his three sons and his armor-bearer and all his men died together that same day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelites along the valley and those across the Jordan saw that the Israelite army had fled and that Saul and his sons had died, they abandoned their towns and fled. And the Philistines came and occupied them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, when the Philistines came to strip the dead, they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They cut off his head and stripped off his armor, and they sent messengers throughout the land of the Philistines to proclaim the news in the temple of their idols and among their people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They put his armor in the temple of the Ashtoreths and fastened his body to the wall of Beth Shan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people of Jabesh Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all their valiant men marched through the night to Beth Shan. They took down the bodies of Saul and his sons from the wall of Beth Shan and went to Jabesh, where they burned them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took their bones and buried them under a tamarisk tree at Jabesh, and they fasted seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator
